reviewText:
This is one of those games you have laying around your place, and your friend boots it up while he's waiting for you to get ready to go somewhere. Cheap laughs, fun to play, with lots of gore, but after watching crowds of zombies be cut up by a lawn mower blade for the 150th time, the game can lose its charm.

Being able to pick up anything off the ground and use it as a weapon is definitly fun, but you slowly start to realise really how little of them actually benefit you. You'd think having hundreds of ways to kill a zombie would be good for some mindeless fun, and it is for the first few hours... but soon enough it grows tedious, and soon you find the zombies are just a bunch of traffic cones that you can easily kick over as they constantly get in your way. They add little challenge to the game, and are literally just walking manaquins for you to unleash your boyhood fantasies of drawing dead stick figuers a hundred times on a blank sheet of paper with a red marker. Its fun, but don't expect something perminant, the gimic of zombie killing wears down quickly, and as soon as you run out of objects to play around with, mowing down zombies is about as exciting as mowing down a lawn, tedious and just a lot of work.  Fortunatly when you get to that point, (and believe me you will) There are several unique and challenging boss fights or psychopaths to take on with your aresonal of orange juice and brooms with a machetes duct taped to the ends. Each one shows signs of multiple psychiatric discorders to reflect the grievance of whatever situation they are cought in. These psychopaths easily steal the show, and I found myself attempting to hunt down each one of them, as each of them were unique, varied, with different weapons and personalities.

I can't exactly say the same for the main story though... This time around in contrast to dead rising 2, you play as Frank West in an alternate story line where he is lazily strapped into the same scenes as Chuck Greene was in from the main game. All the side characters basicaly share almost exactly the same diologue, while Frank might change up a few of Chuck Greene's original lines. You'll more then likely play the main story once then blow it off completely in future attempts of the game as its nothing special, and you probably didn't pick this game up for an enthralling story in the first place. Sorry Frank,, but you're little crysis is as lame as your cheezy one liners. At least with this incardnation of Dead Rising 2, it comes with several DLCs free of charge, and a whole section of the map that was previously blocked off in the vanilla game. Other then that, its nearly the exact same game, just with an alternate story line.If you enjoy violance with all the blood and gore to bath yourself with, then you'll enjoy all your common household objects duct tapped to pointy things as you mindlessly slay walking targets in as multiple ways as the game allows. Fun and cheap, you might come back to it every once in a while for some mindless zombie killing, but without real challenge, it' won't be long before the fun of zombie slaying soon becomes a chore and this game drifts back into your library and remains untouched in till that one bored friend comes over and boots it up. 7.5/10

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2: Off the Record Review
Summary  Pretty much this game is still amazing.  You will have plenty of content here to play with compared to Dead Rising 2.  With this you will have Sandbox Mode, a new area to explore, and more combo weapons.  The story may not be canon to the main story but it is still amazing and worth your time.  Even with the game's performance and optimization problems you will still have a great time with it.  Although if you have played Dead Rising 2 and beat it already, it may not be the best value.  Also avoid coop at all costs unless you want frustration.


Pros and Cons
Pros      Great alternative (But non-canon) story with a great twist near the end!  Worth paying attention too.
Still the same amazing Dead Rising 2 base gameplay, but with a new area to explore and more combo weapons.
Sandbox mode was added for more challenges to do and a unlimited amount of time to slaughter zombies!
This feels like a more complete experience than Dead Rising 2, having way more options, taking out the non-popular Terror is Reality gamemode and adding in Sandbox Mode and a more complete story.  You won't need to play any of the side games or even the first game to realize what happens after the story or before.
Cons      Poorly optimized, I lag a LOT in the Platinum and Silver strip, going down to 25-30FPS when indoors I get a solid 60.
Laughable graphics options, only having the ability to change shadows, atmospheric filtering, and zombie quality.
Crashes EVERYWHERE.  The game crashes when you have the wrong audio settings on your PC, it crashes if you have a long name or name with weird characters on Steam.
This may not even be worth the money to you if you have played Dead Rising 2 to death already.
Terrible coop.  You will constantly get disconnected and you will be hard pressed to play this game with a friend.
Also if you are curious, yes Games for Windows live is gone.

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2: Off the Record is a stand-alone expansion to Dead Rising 2. It is essentially a response to fans of the series who loved the second game but weren't big fans of the protagonist Chuck Greene and wanted a return of Frank West.

In Off the Record you play as Frank West, the protagonist of the original Dead Rising. There are a lot of notable differences the two characters have compared to each other. Frank is a lovable charismatic scoundrel who largely looks out for his own self interest above all else. His animations are also different given how he's much pudgier. You go through mostly the same story and missions as the original, just with Frank instead of Chuck. Frank being the protagonist greatly improves the quality of the story to this game, and it feels like a more natural continuation of the original Dead Rising.

The biggest differences between Off the Record and 2 is in the sidequests. The photography minigame from the original returns, alongside a very much improved endless mode. The endless mode is the biggest reason to pick this game up since Dead Rising 2 lacked it. It allows the player to explore Fortune City with no time limit and additional challenges. The user interface is also much improved.

If you are a fan of the original Dead Rising 2 I guarantee you'll love Off the Record even more. It's exactly what fans of the series originally wanted and delivers in almost every way. I would even recommend it over the original release due to how similar the two experiences are to each other.

One last thing to note is that Capcom graciously patched Games For Windows Live out of both this game and the original Dead Rising 2. So I would greatly recommend the Steam release for it is now the definitive version of the game.

reviewText:
I've spent hundreds of hours playing the Dead Rising series, and there are few games like it. Off the Record really has the most going for it. Dead Rising 2 fixed many issues that Dead Rising 1 had, and OtR polishes DR2 even further. It features all of DR2's famous weapons, plus the photography mechanic from DR1. Many dismiss photography as unnecessary to DR's gameplay, and I disagree. It's a comedic and gory game, and being able to take photos of the mayhem you cause and be rewarded for that turns that into a game mechanic. I can't count the times I wished I could have taken a photo of something unapologetically silly in vanilla DR2 and in DR3.

Co-op mode is a lot of fun. Use the Invite button on the friends list from the in-game menu to ensure you get the partner you want, as the Play Online option on the main menu seems to be only for joining random people's games. The host player will be Frank West as in the single-player mode, while the client is Chuck Greene from vanilla DR2. Chuck's unarmed special moves are functionally similar to, but different from, Frank's, but that the only real difference to learn. He has a camera like Frank too, of course, so both players can take photos of each other doing outrageous things. There is no voice chat, however, so be ready to use Skype or something if you don't want to have to communicate by jumping and running around in circles.

If you haven't played a Dead Rising before, are interested, but are unsure where to begin, I strongly recommend this one over any of the others, including DR3. Should you buy it if you already have DR2? I did, but only because I was buying the PC versions of the games I liked most on 360. For that I am glad it exists, but I wouldn't say there's a point to owning both if you wouldn't already have a reason to own two copies of the same game. The atmosphere just isn't on par. The boss fights lack the unique characterization from DR1, the music seems to not have the same flair either; some tracks just come off generic sometimes. The combat retained the same kind of problems that one had, and getting stuck in a stun animation from a boss never felt more annoying; and the damage limiter that they implemented to how much bosses can get hurt from constant player attack is not a great thing either. Only about three bosses made me feel invested and not frustrated; and this was at higher player levels too.

I can't help the feeling that anything interesting about this game is just a carry over from the first; but there are some meaningful additions that feel like natural and fit into the whole game. Don't get me wrong, I think this is a great game and I had a lot of fun. It's still Dead Rising at heart, and still a unique and fun experience; there is just something missing, but that's just me. If you never got the chance to play Dead Rising on Xbox 360 and really wanna try it, but can't for whatever reason, then I suggest you pick this one up for sure. Sadly this one isn't canon to the story, but rather a what if" unlike the original Dead Rising 2. However that shouldn't push you away from it."

reviewText:
This game is a stand-alone expansion to Dead Rising 2, and it comes with some welcome improvements. It brings back an option to take photos to gain XP, and many of Frank's wrestling moves from Dead Rising 1 return in OTR. The one area that takes a hit is the seriousness of the plot, but if you're playing Dead Rising for a gritty realistic plot, you're probably doing it wrong. Some of the jokes in this game only work if you're familiar with the plot of DR2, but I wouldn't really advise playing both DR2 and DR2 OTR.
OTR also has some different boss battles, new combo weapons, new costumes, and a few small new areas.

If you want to play a DR2, buy this one, not DR2. Of course, while this is an improved DR2, DR3 is leaps and bounds ahead of it in terms of gameplay, storytelling, and overall fun.

As a sidenote: This got ported from GFWL, for which I applaud Capcom. That made it playable. That said, I don't think the keyboard and mouse configuration is at all playable with the quicktime events in this game, and it failed to recognize my MS Xbox 360 wireless controller (which worked fine with DR3), so... maybe wait until they patch that.

~SERIOUS REVIEW~
Dead Rising 2: Off the Record is a great game, with only a few flaws that keep it from being the best game ever.

NOTE: this review is for the Xbox 360 version since my pc is incredibly laggy while playing, and I have put many, many hours into the Xbox port. So, i'm just going to assume that both versions are identical.

-PLOT-
You are Frank West, hero and survivor of the infamous Willamette zombie outbrreak.  Having written a book about it, and  getting YOUR OWN FUC**** TV SHOW, just about you, you are very famous. But one day, that fame is lost, your show has had the plug pulled. You are watching TV, when you see a show called ''Terror Is Reality'' in which contestants earn money for killing thousands of zombies. You think to yourself ''This is my chance to get back in the game!''.
So, for the very beginning of the game, you are pitted against zombies in a wrestling ring and have to kill as many as you can. Once you have won and collected ''THA BIG MONAYYY'', you decide to grab some Zombrex (a drug that stops you from becoming a zombie, spoilers) and head home. However, when you take the elevator, there is a nasty tumble and you pass out. When you awake from your sleep , there are alarms and sirens going off ,screams, and groans. You attempt to wedge open the lift door with all your strength. You can see... *sarcastic gasp* Zombies! To which Frank replies, ''Oh no.'' Just as a certain zombie comes towards you, a running man fortunately runs in front of the zombie, and dies, saving your life. You run out of the arena, into a shelter, along with other survivors. A woman, Stacey, tells you that there is some Zombrex in a nearby plaza. After teaching some looters a lesson, you find a pharmacist (which you take back to the shelter) and some Zombrex. At about 8pm, you go back to the shelter and watch a news report about the incident. Feeling inspired, you must uncover the truth about the outbreak (while brutally murdering thousands upon thousands of zombies), escort innocent survivors, find Zombrex (or buy it for 25 grand) and (hopefully) get back in the game!

-PRESENTATION-
The game looks relatively good. Survivors look like survivors, and Frank looks like, well, Frank West at the age of fourty-one. Where the graphics are mixed, though are the zombies. They look okay at first, but when you play the game more and more, it seems like you've killed a zombie's 119th COMPLETELY IDENTICAL twin. But where the zombies shine, though, are the amount there are. I mean, JESUS, if you have a powerful pc, you can have a thousand zombies on screen before it even drops 1 frame. Even the console ports look good, but i'm saying ''good'' becuz #pcmasterrace :B1: .

-GAMEPLAY-
There are two modes: Story Mode, the mode where â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ actually happens, and Sandbox Mode, which has no plot (kinda), complete freedom,and NO â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ING DRAINING HEALTH BAR FROM INFINITY MODE MY GOD THAT WAS COMPLETE â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥T IN THE FIRST GAM- *cough* and no draining health bar.
New to the mix, are combo weapons. Rather simple, but COMPLETELY NECCESSARY. Examples: Baseball bat+ box o' nails = Spikey bat, Torch + Gems= HOLY â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ A LIGHTSABER.
Simple. Other than that, it's the same run of the mill as the first game: escort idiotic (but slightly better in this game) survivors to a safehouse, get PP, woohoo, do a case mission, get progression in the capcom-tier story, woohoo.
Like the first game, there are Psychopaths, which are the game's bosses. Some are easy, some are hard, some are required, some are optional, some are disgusting, some you want a statue of, lar lar lar, lar.
There's one thing that bugs me though. The same as the first game. THE DIFFICULTY. While it's the complete opposite of  the first game, it's still a problem. Dead Rising 1: OH MY GOODNESS THIS IS THE 2006 VERSION OF SUPER MEAT BOY ON STEROIDS. Dead Rising 2: Off the Record: *grooooooooooooooooooooooooooooan* tooooooooooo easyyyyyyyy. psychopaths are ok though.

-CONCLUSION-
Look past the incredibly easy difficulty, and you have a great game. Don't like plots and time limits like me? There's Sandbox Mode, the godsend from Capcom's usually faulty brain. Want something to do?  There's challenges and the normal story mode. I'll also note that I wouldn't buy this if you have the original DR2.

On a scale of one to ten, this gets a well deserved eight out of ten.  Get it if you have a great PC, it'll be worth the money. Don't have a powerful pc? Get the console port for PS3 and Xbox 360.


I hope you enjoyed my review, and it  made you make up your mind about purchasing the game or not.

reviewText: So, I have been a fan of the series for quite some time. When I was younger, I had a PS3 and really wanted to get an Xbox 360 just to play Dead Rising 1. Dead Rising 1 was absolutely amazing and I loved everything about it. I also pre-ordered Dead Rising 2 for the PS3 when it came out. Dead Rising 2 was good and added a larger mall, combo weapons, and many more secrets and hidden items. And it all comes down to this game, Dead Rising 2: Off the Record. This has improved a bit from Dead Rising 2 by including even more combo weapons, a new vehicle, and my favorite feature, the protagonist as Frank West. Frank actually put on a few pounds after the 5-6 years between the Willamette outbreak and the second Fortune City outbreak. But, this game is a great game to get even for its old release date. If you want to get a good idea about the story, you should maybe start out with Dead Rising 1 or 2. But buy this game if you want to have a lot of fun killing zombies and playing co-op. What is also a great reason to purchase this game is that yesterday it got Steamworks!!!! So you can just join your friends through Steam instead of GFWL (Games for Windows Live). Overall, this is amazing game to get started on the series with, and I will give it a 9/10 because of how much it improved switching to Steamworks. Buy this game whenever it goes on sale and you will have A LOT of fun.

reviewText:
Dead Rising 2: OTR (SP Only) *** Combining DR2 and DR2:OTR ***

Story (5/10):
DR2: OTR's story is largely the same as the other two DR installments. A somewhat bland story, sometimes perked by Capcom's characteristically silly character interactions. Overall, not a strong point of the game.

Gameplay (7/10):
DR2: OTR delivers the same Dead Rising experience that fans of the series have come to know, and sometimes love. Hordes of zombies flood the screen, and as usual, your job is to smite them using a variety of crazy weapons, ranging from laser shooting masks to chainsaw-tipped kayak paddles. DR2 and DR2:OTR really picked up from DR in the sense that they added a LOT of new weapons, which helps the game keep fresh throughout its duration. It personally never got old to smash through piles of enemies using an ever-expanding arsenal of ridiculous armaments. The added infinite mode is worth looking into, since you are unbound by the time constraints of the normal game, and given challenges to complete for money and xp, which carries over into the main game. This can be helpful if you are stuck in the main storyline.

Unfortunately, this is where the fun ends. As with previous DR installments, boss fights are tedious and cheap, escorts are constant and frustrating, and many parts of the game feel drawn out and devoid of content or direction. If you are not satisfied with killing zombies, you will find little else of value in this game.

Mechanics (6/10):
DR2/DR2:OTR's new mechanic is the weapon combination mechanic, which allows you to combine weapons into new devastating combinations. This system is unfortunately limited by your need to find/unlock blueprints to use combo weapons to their full potentional, as well as the need to find specific maintenance rooms" where the combos can be made. A more on-the-fly system may have been easier. Otherwise

I always thought the dead rising games looked too goofy for me... Then I played the third one... and that was one of the most hardcore gaming experiences ever... so I came and bought this one since 3 will sadly be xbox exclusive (I cant blame em either)

Now, this one is not in anyway as good as the third one... but it's still a pretty good game...
It's really how you let yourself experience the game. There is some system that determines what kinda weapons you unlock, maybe how you play, idk... the multiplayer is touchy (maybe because of the off the record part of it less people own it) I have yet to be able to join a game, but if I'm playing for an hour or so someone usually joins my game... which is such a sweet suprise when your playing and suddenly someone else is there. It's kinda neat that way... This one's story is a little wonky but its basically a DLC add content... but its still pretty good. The story is good, just sometimes during a cutscene or something some survivor made you strip all your clothes off to save them and of course youre at the serious moment of a cutscene when that happens... soo... that always happens...

I'll let you know what the best experience is in this game. You find some awesome mask, some kool shirt... you look like some zombie apocolypse ninja dude... you got a weapon made out of two fireaxes and a sledgehammer... a bunch of other insane things... youre standing on top of a flipped over truck surrounded by hundreds of zombies... you got an online buddy dropping in wearing a tux... and you guys go to town. You fight and fight and fight... you end up having to scournge for food on your last leg... get back out and fight and fight... ah man...

The goofyness is what deterred me before but it needs to be there simply because of the insanity and violence of the game... for the entire series... the overall story is actually really good. Probably better than resident evil has been in a long time.

If you get a chance tho... play the third one... that game is amazing.

reviewText:
Don't buy this game. Get DR2 instead. Game is a mess and the DLC won't always work!

So first off, let me say that I absolutely loved and enjoyed my time with Dead Rising 2. Dead Rising 2 is a stable, well-running, non-crashing game that I have played for over 100 hours and counting with ZERO issues. It can easily run at 1080p/60fps and is a great port. Go ahead and buy it right now. It is worth it and so is the DLC. Get it on a sale, have fun with it!

Whatever you do, stay as far away from this game as possible. Off the Record has given me nothing but headaches and in addition it has practically stolen my money. Let me just go ahead and list the issues I have encountered in my time with this game, and I repeat, none of these things occur in Dead Rising 2:

Game runs at least 20 frames below DR2 in open areas.
Random crashes during the game. Just random. It's a mess.
New weapons can cause glitches and crashes (Alien Helmet + Gems Combo -> Hold X attack can crash the game)
PC Settings -> Blur Effects option is glitched and no longer turns off what it should.
Alt Tabbing can crash the game
DLC may appear as CORRUPTED and cannot be accessed. IF YOU BUY THE DLC YOUR MONEY MAY BE GONE AND YOU MIGHT GET NOTHING
New glitches in picking up items, especially near a crafting table. Its annoying.
Swords, katanas and other blade weapons have glitches now. The jump + x attack can randomly not work anymore and always miss by 45 degrees.
Essential items are locked out of Sandbox mode
The save sound effect is way louder than any other sounds and makes me jump every time
Saving takes forever now, since the game needs 10 seconds to 'Check for saves'.
Glitches weapons can randomly appear in the game, like a non-functioning AK-47 that was never finished.

I could go on but you get the point. It's not worth it, the developers are NEVER going to fix all of these issues so stick to Dead Rising 2, enjoy it for the great game that it is and skip Off The Record. They took a fantastic, stable, well-running game and turned it into a pile of garbage with nothing but issues after issues.

I hope I saved you some money. Instead, spend that money on the original, well-made Dead RIsing 2.

reviewText:
I first played DR2 as a free game though the Xbox 360's Games with Gold program. I would end up getting over 30 million PP. Unfortunately, the PC versions of DR2 and OTR use Games For Window Live, but I won't take points off for that. The Arkham games had used them for so long and just recently have been released with clean versions.

Dead Rising 2 improves on all fronts where Dead Rising 1 left off. It introduces combo weapons, which are a more efficient way to get PP to level up than saving survivors alone. The AI of the survivors is no longer frustrating, they can defend themselves better than ever and follow directions. Granted they're not quite AS smart in Off The Record on PC compared to DR2 vanilla on PC, but OTR has check points. There are a few psychopath bosses, they adjusted the survivor roster, there's more combo cards and a whole new section of the map called Uranus Zone. That whole part of the map was under construction in DR2 vanilla.... so lead it to Capcom to make you buy the game twice to play the full game just like Street Fighter IV. There's a lot to hate about Capcom since Resident Evil 5 came out, but I love DR2 and Off The Record in the definitive version here on PC. I love the time management, the frantic decisions and scheduling you have to do to rescue as many people as possible. The PP (Prestige Point) gives it arcade fun and I find myself still playing DR2 after reaching the max level of 50. I can't get bored of this game. If I start playing I gotta keep going until I reach a point where after I save it'll be a book marked time in the story of a playthrough.

Dead Rising gets my vote for the most improved series since 2005. DR1 was a frustrating game, a 360 exclusive with an antiquated save system. DR2 improved everything and added so much more, then Off The Record raised it as if the Chuck Greene game was incomplete. I really wish DR3 wasn't an XB1 exclusive. I'm done with consoles, love live Steam! You should've have to buy extra hardware for segregated limited platforms. Resident Evil series get's worst fall from grace since Resident Evil 4 topped off the series in 2005.

Through whatever flaws Dead Rising 2 Off The Record has, I give it a 5/5. It's not for everyone, especially if you have ADD and blame the game for your short comings in attention. You gotta play the game like a speed run as much as you can and take every advantage with you including combo weapons, skill books and mixed drinks. Don't play it dumb and you'll be alright.
After playing the hell out of DR2 on 360, I completed OTR on PC within 3 days without having to restart the story. I went from level 1-42 in my first playthrough.

5/5

reviewText: Dead Rising 2: Off the Record is basically an updated and better version of Dead Rising 2.  As a game on it's own, it is very fun and engaging as it allows you to unravel the story in the game or simply mess around with anything that surrounds you.  During your time in the game you encounter bosses known as psychopathes every now and then.  While the world you play in is plauged by zombies, the real threat is the people, and battling these psychos prove to be very difficult when you are not prepared to take them on.\n\nCompared to Dead Rising 2, the main difference is the story; instead of playing as Chuck Greene, who needs to find zombrex for his daughter and trying to clear his name from being framed during the outbreak, you play as Frank West who tries to uncover the incident behind the outbreak.  Gameplay wise, the two games are mostly the same, but OTR pulls it off somewhat better, as it has a sandbox mode that replaces DR2's TIR (Terror is Reality) Contests, fine-tuned game mechanics and a photography mode that originates from the first Dead Rising game.  If you've already played Dead Rising 2 you won't find yourself playing a completely new game.  If you haven't though, then this version is the better version.  Both versions support co-op, but the two games cannot intercommunicate with eachother, so if you're planning to play with a friend, make sure he owns the same version as you do or plan to get.  The only reasons you would own both DR2 and OTR is that you are interested in the changed game mechanics and story, manage to pick up DR2 complete for a great price, or simply because you know Frank West has covered wars, you know.

reviewText:
So yeah. This is my first review, but then, this is one of the games I know intimately well. I may only have about 16 hours on record here, but I've logged far more on the 360 version.

The Dead Rising series seems a bit schlocky, and that's not surprising. It's meant to be a tongue-in-cheek take on zombie outbreaks. It remains serious enough to have a cohesive plot, but not so serious that a lot of the bosses and scenarios you encounter seem far-fetched or histrionic.

The fun very much comes from having a whole playground of casinos, mall shops, and an added amusement park to formulate weapons and combat them. In addition to that, you'll encounter a lot of survivors who need to be brought back to the safehouse.

Then there's the sandbox mode. It takes out the merciless clock and timer that often impeded your missions in Dead Rising 2 and the original Dead Rising. That really allows for it to be your playground.

There's a bit of humor, a bit of sexy, a 'reality' TV show that glorifies zombie-killing in a WWE-type format. And what's more: Frank West returns in the Off the Record rendition.

Some of its reviews both here and elsewhere tend to be a bit negatory because DR2:OTR took so very much from DR2... so much that, heck, a lot of it's exactly the same. But what OTR really does is fine-tune, improve, and give a little more freedom. It makes it a lot more fun. It's what kept me coming back. I've probably played through the story twenty to thirty times now... and I expect to keep going. The ride's that fun.

Grab a weapon. Get creative. Explore. You'll find plenty of crazies along the way.

reviewText: Dead Rising 2: Off the Record is basically an updated and better version of Dead Rising 2.  As a game on it's own, it is very fun and engaging as it allows you to unravel the story in the game or simply mess around with anything that surrounds you.  During your time in the game you encounter bosses known as psychopathes every now and then. Gameplay wise, the two games are mostly the same, but OTR pulls it off somewhat better, as it has a sandbox mode that replaces DR2's TIR (Terror is Reality) Contests, fine-tuned game mechanics and a photography mode that originates from the first Dead Rising game.  If you've already played Dead Rising 2 you won't find yourself playing a completely new game.  If you haven't though, then this version is the better version.  Both versions support co-op, but the two games cannot intercommunicate with eachother, so if you're planning to play with a friend, make sure he owns the same version as you do or plan to get.  The only reasons you would own both DR2 and OTR is that you are interested in the changed game mechanics and story, manage to pick up DR2 complete for a great price, or simply because you know Frank West has covered wars, you know.

reviewText:
Essentially the same game...

Originally posted by DR2 review:Dumb & simple zombie killing fun.

Like the first game, weapons and health are generally all around you only this time around you can combine two specific items to make another weapon that's possibly cooler, sillier, practical, or a combination of a number of those. You can find out what item goes with what via Combo Cards which are unlocked through general progression of the game such as examining certain posters, leveling, defeating psychopaths, etc. You can combine items without the specific card however the item produced won't be as effective and rewarding. It's highly encouraging to produce the Combo Weapons because using them generally nets you PP for leveling and curiosity in how they'll work will become pretty high.

You're free to run around the world as you please (aside from some areas that can only unlocked from doing certain missions) though its criticized time limit makes a return so you only have so much time to get to doing the missions. If you stick to doing missions, not be as distracted, and perhaps if you're at a decent level it won't feel like it's rushing you to go do something so much. Even if you fail a task no matter how important and until the timer runs out or you choose to restart the story you're free to run around freely doing whatever. Restarting the specific save file's story allows you to keep your level, money, and Combo Cards for that next playthrough.

The plot & dialogue is full of cheese, especially with the psychopaths. I think it's for the better that that's the case.

There isn't much depth to the actual zombie killing aside from just having good weapons for the situation and the psychopath fights. The psychopaths can be extremely cheap in their own special way but at least for most of the fights you're free to leave and return to the area in case you don't feel ready for the boss fight.

The co-op's overall doable. A bit easier (if no lag is present) but adds enjoyment to the game. The money and level you've earned anywhere in a save file can be used in both single player and co-op where the only thing that doesn't carry over for either is the story if you're not hosting the game. The entire thing could have probably used an implemented in-game chat and give-item-to-partner feature as opposed to dropping or chucking the item for them to pick it up.

Fetch quests, escorts, and just messing around. Probably better with a controller since keys are unrebindable.
...but now it's slightly not as optimized, there's a new area for you to explore, some new items & Combo Weapons, some new survivors, many familiar items and survivors have been relocated for better or worse, the story's a teensy bit altered, there's a Sandbox Mode" for you to run amok in without fear of a timer where your progress in it carries over to the story mode and vice versa

reviewText: Still one of my favorite childhood games and series. Dead Rising 2 Off The Record takes a what if story viewpoint of number 2. Basically Off The Record is the story of Dead Rising 2 with Frank West as the main character. Personally in my opinion this is far more better then the original Dead Rising 2, don't get me wrong I like Chuck Greene and his story in the original number 2 but Frank West is still my favorite character in the Dead Rising series and I really did enjoy the small little changes to the story line to make it Frank's own unique story. For most of the game the storyline is pretty similiar to number 2 just with Frank of course like I mentioned along with small little changes. There is now a really enjoyable sandbox mode where you can run around Fortune City and do whatever you want along with killing all the pyschopaths as well. Everything else is still the same basically like co-op mode and what not but there are a few new psychopaths and survivors in Off The Record along with Uranus Zone the newest add on to Fortune City. Overall this game is a hell lot of fun especially with a friend me personally went through the storyline with my girlfriend who never played Dead Rising so it was quite the adventure. Personally I think it's worth the $20 hell I would pay even more for it but if you are a cheap type of person I'd wait till it goes on sale.

reviewText:
As somebody who owns and has played both Dead Rising 2 and Dead Rising 2: Off the Record, I will be comparing it to Dead Rising 2

Pros:
More Combo weapons
Taking Pictures
New Bosses
Sandbox Mode
Frank West's humour
Concept art gallery

Cons:
New Bosses: As much as I like the replacement for the Leon Bell fight (not saying who his replacement is), the new final boss is worse in all aspects. It feels like one big gimmick, and since all of the buildup for Dead Rising 2's twist boss is unchanged, the new boss just comes off as forced. Whereas the other new boss is just lame and annoying with bland music.
More bugs, ranging from helpful (infinite paddlesaw) to irritating (Weapons clipping through the floor) to even horrendous (getting stuck on things)
Online is worse
No graphics options
Removal of Terror is Reality (far from a dealbreaker imo)

Overall, I prefer Dead Rising 2, but Off the Record from pure content is a better game. I prefer 2's storytelling, though Off the Record does have it's moments of great narrative (working Brandon into the main story was cool). If you just want story and some fun get 2, but if you want more ways to kill zombies and more time to kill zombies(or just even if you enjoyed 2) I recommend Off the Record.
